statement.p: [MIT OCW] A system of linear equations Ax=b cannot have exactly two solutions. An easy way to see why: if two vectors x and y \ne x are two solutions (i.e. Ax=band Ay=b), what is another solution? (Hint: x+y is almost right.)

answer.p: Ax=b and Ay=b, so A(x+y)=Ax+Ay=2b. [The key property that A(x+y)=Ax+Ay is called linearity, and is what makes matrix multiplication a part of linear algebra.] But we want b on the right-hand side, so we can just divide both sides by 2: A((x+y)/2)=b, so (x+y)/2 is a solution. (Since x \ne y, this is a new solution, halfway between x and y.)
